repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
- Added an lpeg grammar for LuaCATS (with typing)
- Use it in `lua2dox.lua` and simplified it.
- All types are now rendered as ```(`type`)```
- Render optional types using `?` instead of `|nil`

comment_data.body:
Awesome! This is already a great improvement, but it seems that more complex types like `any[]|nil` are not captured.

```suggestion
local TYPE_PAT = '[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z_.%[%]|]*'
```

With the above we can deal with simple array and union types, e.g. `foo[]|nil`.

Function types that contain `?`, `,` `(`, `)`, etc. might be quite complicated to process with regex (we'll need treesitter parsing eventually....), so this might be addressed as a separate scope. `function(..)`s are already clear themselves, so it'd be okay not putting them in the (parentheses).

We can also capture the `optional?` types:

```suggestion
local TYPE_PAT = '[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z_.%[%]|?]*'
```
There are only a few such occurrences, `(string?)`, `(Version ?|nil)`, etc.
I don't think treesitter would ever be the right tool for this. Instead I've implemented an lpeg grammar to capture many more types.

This is sort of a regression, however I think we should either surround all types with backticks or not at all.

@clason?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -860,7 +860,7 @@ vim.spell.check({str})                                     *vim.spell.check()*
       • {str}  (string)
 
     Return: ~
-        `{[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]` List of tuples with three
+        ({[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]) List of tuples with three

comment_data.body: FWIW, (unlocking) improvements in our tooling is a valid argument for standardizing type annotations.

I think multiple (variable) returns is like: `@return string...\n@return string[]...`

https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/#return
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,108 @@
+local helpers = require('test.functional.helpers')(after_each)
+local eq = helpers.eq
+
+local grammar = require('src/nvim/generators/luacats_grammar')
+
+describe('luacats grammar', function()
+  --- @param text string
+  --- @param exp table<string,string>
+  local function test(text, exp)
+    it(string.format('can parse %q', text), function()
+      eq(exp, grammar:match(text))
+    end)
+  end
+
+  test('@param hello vim.type', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'vim.type',
+  })
+
+  test('@param hello vim.type this is a description', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'vim.type',
+    desc = 'this is a description'
+  })
+
+  test('@param hello vim.type|string this is a description', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'vim.type|string',
+    desc = 'this is a description'
+  })
+
+  test('@param hello vim.type?|string? this is a description', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'vim.type?|string?',
+    desc = 'this is a description'
+  })
+
+  test('@return string hello this is a description', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'string',
+    desc = 'this is a description'
+  })
+
+  test('@return fun() hello this is a description', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'fun()',
+    desc = 'this is a description'
+  })
+
+  test('@return fun(a: string[]): string hello this is a description', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'fun(a: string[]): string',
+    desc = 'this is a description'
+  })
+
+  test('@return fun(a: table<string,any>): string hello this is a description', {
+    name = 'hello',
+    type = 'fun(a: table<string,any>): string',
+    desc = 'this is a description'
+  })
+
+  test('@param ... string desc', {
+    name = '...',
+    type = 'string',
+    desc = 'desc'
+  })
+
+  test('@param level (integer|string) desc', {
+    name = 'level',
+    type = '(integer|string)',
+    desc = 'desc'
+  })
+
+  test('@return (string command) the command and arguments', {
+    name = 'command',
+    type = 'string',
+    desc = 'the command and arguments'
+  })
+
+  test('@return (string command, string[] args) the command and arguments', {

comment_data.body: I think the backticks help with reading complex return types, but I agree: since the vast majority of type annotations uses parens, deviating adds (a little) friction. So they're not worth keeping around, especially if this makes docgen easier/more robust.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -860,7 +860,7 @@ vim.spell.check({str})                                     *vim.spell.check()*
       • {str}  (string)
 
     Return: ~
-        `{[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]` List of tuples with three
+        ({[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]) List of tuples with three

comment_data.body:
I'd prefer backticks, since parens are not highlighted. But surrounding complex functions with parens `(function(...: any):table[]|nil?)` seems also fine.

If we use backticks for all types, some will lose links to helptags (e.g. |TSNode|), but I think having links would be useful for some types.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -860,7 +860,7 @@ vim.spell.check({str})                                     *vim.spell.check()*
       • {str}  (string)
 
     Return: ~
-        `{[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]` List of tuples with three
+        ({[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]) List of tuples with three

comment_data.body: Links are more important than highlighting, IMO.

@@ -860,7 +860,7 @@ vim.spell.check({str})                                     *vim.spell.check()*
       • {str}  (string)

+        ({[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]) List of tuples with three

comment_data.body:
The backticks are trivial to add, it's really a matter of preference. I would vote to add them since it reduces the chance of vimdoc parse errors as types can be complicated expressions. The downside would that we wouldn't be able to use the types as tags.

Don't need to make a decision now, I've not included them in this PR to reduce the diff.

comment_data.body:
For links: it seems that `CTRL-]` on the following anchor can work, correctly jumps to `*TSNode*`:

```
|`TSNode`|

:help `TSNode`
```

However, this doesn't work (while `CTRL-]` can jump):
```
:help `|TSNode|`
```

+        ({[1]: string, [2]: string, [3]: string}[]) List of tuples with three

comment_data.body: Oh didn't know that. TIL, thanks! I'm gonna fix the luadoc treesitter parser.

comment_data.body: 💯 Working around those pipe conflicts was annoying.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -630,75 +631,75 @@ get_node({opts})                                   *vim.treesitter.get_node()*
                   true)
 
     Return: ~
-        |TSNode| | nil Node at the given position
+        (`TSNode?`) Node at the given position
 
 get_node_range({node_or_range})              *vim.treesitter.get_node_range()*
     Returns the node's range or an unpacked range table
 
     Parameters: ~
-      • {node_or_range}  (|TSNode| | table) Node or table of positions
+      • {node_or_range}  (`TSNode|table`) Node or table of positions

comment_data.body: Loss of typing?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -940,8 +939,8 @@ lint({buf}, {opts})                              *vim.treesitter.query.lint()*
     for the `lua` language will be used.
 
     Parameters: ~
-      • {buf}   (integer) Buffer handle
-      • {opts}  (QueryLinterOpts|nil) Optional keyword arguments:
+      • {buf}   (`integer`) Buffer handle
+      • {opts}  (`table?`) Optional keyword arguments:

comment_data.body:
I did this on purpose since the type isn't used anywhere else.

Basically, if you do:
```
--- @param name some.complicated.type (table) desc
```

It will render the type as `table` instead of `some.complcated.type`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -940,8 +939,8 @@ lint({buf}, {opts})                              *vim.treesitter.query.lint()*
     for the `lua` language will be used.
 
     Parameters: ~
-      • {buf}   (integer) Buffer handle
-      • {opts}  (QueryLinterOpts|nil) Optional keyword arguments:
+      • {buf}   (`integer`) Buffer handle
+      • {opts}  (`table?`) Optional keyword arguments:

comment_data.body: I forgot about that. I guess that's another reason to not do the tagging since it conflicts too much with unions.

comment_data.body:
Yeah. The loss of help links is a blow for treesitter specifically (I don't think we use much userdata elsewhere?), but that help needs more love anyway. 

We can always tack a simple `|TSNode|` at the end of the annotation comment (if there's not a link elsewhere in the docs already).

     Parameters: ~
-      • {node_or_range}  (|TSNode| | table) Node or table of positions
+      • {node_or_range}  (`TSNode|table`) Node or table of positions

comment_data.body: Did we consider dropping the parens? Especially since we have backticks now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -475,55 +475,55 @@ config({opts}, {namespace})                          *vim.diagnostic.config()*
                        severities are displayed before lower severities (e.g.
                        ERROR is displayed before WARN). Options:
                        • reverse: (boolean) Reverse sort order
-      • {namespace}  (integer|nil) Update the options for the given namespace.
+      • {namespace}  (`integer?`) Update the options for the given namespace.

comment_data.body: No but we could do. I kind of like the parens since it makes it clear it is separate from the description, but I don't feel super strong about it. The backticks will be concealed but will add highlighting.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -475,55 +475,55 @@ config({opts}, {namespace})                          *vim.diagnostic.config()*
                        severities are displayed before lower severities (e.g.
                        ERROR is displayed before WARN). Options:
                        • reverse: (boolean) Reverse sort order
-      • {namespace}  (integer|nil) Update the options for the given namespace.
+      • {namespace}  (`integer?`) Update the options for the given namespace.

comment_regular_data.body:
- I've added backticks since there were some vimdoc errors, and tbh I think it makes complicated types easier to read.
- Converted `|nil` -> `?` since we can now say we are just using LuaCATS notation.

> Converted |nil -> ? since we can now say we are just using LuaCATS notation.

Very nice. Should we document this somewhere (for _users_, who may not read `develop.txt`)?
Yes I considered that, but didn't know where.

Yeah, that's the big question. Maybe in `lua.txt` somewhere? Or at the top of  `api.txt`?

Not critical, though, and can be left for later.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

title: fix(doc): improve doc generation of types using lpeg
